TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy, mixed, superactive, mesic Typic Haploxerolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Laki loam, cultivated.  (Colors are for moist soil unless otherwise noted.)
Ap--0 to 8 inches; very dark brown (10YR 2/2) loam, grayish brown (10YR 4/2) dry; weak thin platy and weak fine granular structure; friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine roots, many very fine pores; few reddish brown and brown fine concretions; weakly effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 7.9); clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 10 inches thick)
A--8 to 15 inches; very dark brown (10YR 2/2) loam, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) dry; weak medium prismatic structure parting to weak fine granular; friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine roots; many very fine pores; weakly effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); clear smooth boundary.  (5 to 10 inches thick)
AB--15 to 19 inches; very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) loam, grayish brown (10YR 5/2) dry; weak medium subangular blocky structure; friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine roots; many very fine tubular pores; few fine flecks and streaks of lime; weakly effervescent; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 10 inches thick)
Bw--19 to 32 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) loam, light brownish gray (10YR 6/2) dry; weak medium subangular blocky structure; friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine roots; many very fine tubular pores; few grayish brown coatings in pores; few firm aggregates; strongly effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.8); gradual wavy boundary.  (8 to 20 inches thick)
C1--32 to 48 inches; dark brown (10YR 4/3) loam, light gray (10YR 7/2) dry; massive; soft, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few roots; many very fine tubular pores; few firm aggregates; strongly effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.9); clear wavy boundary.  (10 to 20 inches thick)
C2--48 to 60 inches; dark grayish brown (10YR 4/2) loam, light gray (10YR 7/1) dry; weak thick platy structure; hard, friable and firm, slightly sticky, and nonplastic; many very fine and fine, few medium tubular pores; strongly effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.6).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Klamath County, Oregon; 1,280 feet east and 1,930 feet south of the NW corner section 31, T. 39 S., R. 11 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 48 to 51 degrees F.  The soils are usually moist and are dry for 45 to 70 days in the summer.  Depth to bedrock is more than 60 inches.  The mollic epipedon is 10 to 20 inches thick.  Sodium saturation is erratic with depth and the sodium absorption ratio commonly ranges from 10 to 25.  Conductivity of the saturation extract ranges from less than 1 to 16 mmhos/cm.  Carbonates commonly are present throughout the soil and range from a trace to about 10 percent.  The soils lack soft, powdery secondary lime within 1 meter of the surface.  The 10 to 40 inch control section is loam or fine sandy loam and averages 18 to 25 percent clay, estimated by 2.5 times 15 bar water values.  Field estimated clay mostly is about 10 to 18 percent.
The A horizon has value of 2 or 3 moist, 4 or 5 dry, and chroma of 1 or 2 moist and dry.  It is loam, fine sandy loam, or sandy loam.
The Bw horizon has hue of 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 3 or 4 moist, 6 or 7 dry, and chroma of 2 or 3 moist and 1 or 2 dry.
The C horizon has hue of neutral, 10YR or 2.5Y, value of 3 through 6 moist, 6 through 8 dry, and chroma of 1 through 3 moist and 0 through 3 dry.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Crowshaw, Lovline, Odo and Tocaloma series.  Crowshaw and Odo soils are noncalcareous throughout.  Lovline and Tocaloma soils are 20 to 40 inches deep to bedrock.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Laki soils are on nearly level terraces at elevations of 4,035 to 4,800 feet.  The soils formed in lacustrine sediments weathered from basalt, tuff, diatomite and ash.  The climate is semiarid with warm dry summers and cold moist winters.  The mean annual precipitation is 10 to 15 inches.  The mean January temperature is 27 to 29 degrees F., the mean July temperature is 65 to 69 degrees F., and the mean annual temperature is 46 to 49 degrees F.  The frost-free period is 50 to 110 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Calimus, Fordney, Henley and Hosley soils.  Calimus and Fordney soils are noncalcareous to depths of more than 40 inches.  Calimus soils also have a mollic epipedon thicker than 20 inches and Fordney soils have a sandy control section.  Henley and Hosley soils have a duripan at depths of 20 to 40 inches and Hosley soils also have a natric horizon.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Moderately well drained; very slow runoff; moderate permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  The soils are used for irrigated crops including potatoes, alfalfa hay, barley, wheat, oats, pasture and annual hay crops.  They also are used for homesites and wildlife habitat.  Native vegetation dominantly is rabbitbrush, greasewood and saltgrass.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Lake basins in south-central Oregon and northern California.  The soils are moderately extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Klamath County, Oregon, 1967.
REMARKS:
The superactive cation exchange activity class was added in 03/2003 to the taxonomic classification by the National Soil Survey Center on request of the Reno MLRA office, without review of the soil series property data. The remainder of this document has not been updated.
ADDITIONAL DATA:  Characterization data on 2 profiles (S67 Oreg. 18-3 and 18-6) reported in Riverside Soil Survey Laboratory report for Laki soils sampled in Klamath County, Oregon, 1967.  Profile 18-3 is the type location.
REMARKS:
The superactive cation exchange activity class was added in 03/2003 to the taxonomic classification by the National Soil Survey Center on request of the Reno MLRA office, without review of the soil series property data. The remainder of this document has not been updated.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
